Aluminium oxide (Al2O3) is a promising catalyst support due to its excellent stability, high specific surface area, low price, and wide applicability. At present, most of the synthesis methods of Al2O3 are wet chemical process, and the solid-state synthesis of catalysts is underdeveloped under solvent-free conditions. In this study, we proposed a novel strategy for solvent-free synthesis of Rh/Al2O3 catalysts via mechanochemistry. The pore properties of the catalysts can be tuned by simply adjusting the amount of template CTAB and calcination temperatures. As a proof of concept, as-prepared catalysts are used to catalyze hydrolytic dehydrogenation of ammonia borane. The best catalyst Rh/Al2O3-CTAB(0.4)-500 achieves a total turnover frequency of 186.0 molH2·molRh −1·min−1 at 298 K and the activation energy is 44.8 kJ·mol−1. It also exhibits good cycling properties for catalyzing the hydrolysis of ammonia borane completely even after five runs. The catalysts were also characterized by various methods, including SEM, TEM, XPS, XRD, etc., to study the relationship between their structure and catalytic performance. The results show that the high activity of the catalyst is closely related to its large BET specific surface area and appropriate average pore size. Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract . Keywords Ammonia borane Hydrolysis Mechanochemistry Hydrogen generation Rhodium Data Availability No data was used for the research described in the article. 1 Introduction Nowadays, due to the rapid development of industry and population growth, the consumption of fossil fuels is increasing, which not only leads to a serious energy crisis, but also causes environmental deterioration. Therefore, the exploration and development of renewable and clean energy have become an important direction in the field of energy and environmental research [1,2]. Hydrogen has attracted great attention as a high-energy, clean, and environmentally friendly ideal carrier of renewable energy, and is expected to become a substitute for traditional fossil fuels to solve the increasingly serious energy crisis and environmental problems [3]. Although hydrogen has such advantages as high calorific value and easy availability, its gaseous nature is not conducive to storage and transportation, which is also the biggest obstacle to its practical application. Therefore, there is an urgent need for a suitable hydrogen storage material to solve this problem. Ammonia borane (AB), as the simplest B-N compound, has many advantages of non-toxicity, stability in aqueous solution, high hydrogen content (19.6 wt%), and low molar weight (30.7 g·mol−1), which make it one of the most promising hydrogen storage materials [4–7]. Although AB has many advantages as a carrier for storing and transporting hydrogen, its hydrogen evolution reaction needs to be carried out under specific conditions, such as heating or the presence of appropriate catalysts. Up to now, there are three ways of hydrogen production from AB: pyrolysis [8,9], methanolysis [10,11], and hydrolysis [12,13]. Among them, hydrolysis is the most effective way to release H2 from AB because of its advantages such as low energy consumption and mild reaction conditions. It is one of the key issues to develop effective catalysts for hydrogen production from AB [14–17]. Many active catalysts have therefore been designed and reported. In 2006, Xu et al. first reported the hydrolysis of AB using precious [18] or non-precious [19] metals as catalysts. Since then, a large number of metal catalysts used for AB hydrolysis have been reported, including noble metals (such as palladium [20], rhodium [21–23], platinum [24,25], ruthenium [26–28], gold [29] and non-noble metals (such as cobalt [30,31], copper [32,33], nickel [34,35], and iron [36]). These studies show that the precious metal catalysts are the mainstay because of their high catalytic activity, but the inherent high price of precious metals limits their practical application, and the agglomeration of metal in nanometer size leads to the masking of active sites, thereby impairing their catalytic activities [37]. Therefore, the key factor to improve the catalytic effects of the catalysts is to find a suitable support, and the use of supports also facilitates the recovery of catalysts. At present, the most used supports include carbon [38,39], metal-organic frameworks [40], metal oxides [41,42], zeolites [43], and silica [44]. Metal oxide supports are widely used because of their low price and good stability. Among various metal oxides, aluminium oxide (Al2O3) is regarded as one of the most promising mesoporous materials or supports because of its excellent properties such as excellent stability, widespread availability, high surface area, abundant sources, low price, and environmental friendliness. So far, Rh0/Al2O3(0.5%wt. Rh) is the highest activity catalyst with a turnover frequency of only 195 min−1 in hydrogen generation from the hydrolysis of AB among the reported Al2O3 supported Rh catalysts [45]. In addition, the binding method of loading the active components on the carrier Al2O3 will also affect the activity of the catalyst. The common methods of loading metals include coprecipitation, impregnation, etc. [46–47]. But these methods are complex and require solvents, which not only increases the consumption of energy and time, but also produces liquid waste. Therefore, it is quite plausible to give effort for developing an effective catalyst preparation method and improving the catalytic activity of Rh/Al2O3 towards hydrolysis of AB. Herein, we report a one-pot organic-inorganic self-assembly strategy for the preparation of Rh/Al2O3 catalysts by mechanochemistry, replacing traditional solvent-based technology. This solid-state process is realized by directly ball milling aluminum nitrate and RhCl3·3H2O, which is green, solvent-free, simple, energy- and time-saving [48,49]. The prepared catalysts show good catalytic activity for the hydrolytic dehydrogenation of AB, significantly higher than those previously reported catalysts, and its turnover frequency (TOF) and activation energy (E a) are 186.0 molH2·molRh −1·min−1 and 44.8 kJ·mol−1 at 25°C, respectively. 2 Experimental section 2.1 Materials RhCl3·3H2O (Rh 39%), hexadecyl trimethyl ammonium bromide (CTAB) were purchased from Energy Chemical Company. Ammonia borane (AB, 90 wt.%) was purchased from Aladdin reagent (Shanghai) Co., Ltd. Aluminium nitrate nonahydrate was purchased from Shanghai Titan Scientific Co., Ltd. Aluminium nitrate nonahydrate was dried in a vacuum oven for 48 h prior to use, all other chemicals were used without further purification. 2.2 Characterization The specific surface area was determined by a BSD-PM2 physical adsorption meter, produced by Beishide Instrument Technology (Beijing) Co., Ltd. The pore size distribution (PSD) was calculated by the BJH model from the adsorption branches of the isotherms. Powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) patterns were measured by a Bruker D8 Advance X-ray diffractometer with a Cu Ka source (40 kV, 40 mA). X-ray photoelectron spectrometry (XPS) was performed on a Thermo Scientific K-Alpha equipped with an Al Kα source. Inductively coupled plasma mass spectrometry (Agilent 7800 ICP-MS) was used to determine the rhodium content in catalysts. The morphology of these samples was checked by scanning electron microscopy (SEM, Hitachi S-3400N) and transmission electron microscopy (TEM, FEI G2 F20). 2.3 Preparation for Rh/Al2O3 Catalysts are synthesized by mechanochemical methods shown in Scheme 1 . In a typical synthesis process of mesoporous Rh/Al2O3, we add 1.0 g of aluminum nitrate, 0.4 g of CTAB and 10 mg of RhCl3·3H2O into a 50ml zirconia ball mill containing zirconia balls (10 balls of 10 mm, 10 balls of 8 mm, and 5 balls of 5 mm). They are then ground in a planetary ball mill (YXQM-0.4L produced by MITR Company, Hunan Province, China) for half an hour without the addition of solvent. This process produces a yellow mixture which means the completion of organic-inorganic self-assembly between reactants (e.g., aluminum nitrate as precursor and CTAB as the template). We then transfer the mixture into a tubular furnace at a heating rate of 2°C/min to 400°C and roasted for 2h in air to ensure the complete decomposition of CTAB into the gaseous product. After cooling to room temperature, the product was washed with water three times, and then dried overnight in a vacuum oven. The prepared sample was named Rh/Al2O3-CTAB(0.4)-400. Other samples were also synthesized according to the above procedure and denoted as Rh/Al2O3-CTAB(X)-T (where X represents the amount of CTAB and T represents the roasting temperature). 2.4 Catalytic property of Rh/Al2O3 in the hydrolysis of AB The catalysts were used for the hydrolysis of AB, and the catalytic activity of these catalysts was evaluated by monitoring the H2 release rate. The amount of hydrogen was measured with a water displacement method. A two-neck reactor containing a certain mass of catalyst is placed in a thermostatic water bath with magnetic stirring, one neck was connected to a water displacement equipment and the other is plugged with a rubber plug. The reaction started once the AB solution (2 ml, 0.25 M) was added into the reactor with a syringe, and the data is recorded every 30 s. To determine the most active catalyst, the reaction was performed starting with different catalysts (10 mg) at 298 K. The total turnover frequency (TOF) is calculated by the following formula: TOF = n H 2 n Rh × t Hydrolysis reaction of AB is performed starting with AB (2 mL, 0.25 M) and optimal catalyst Rh/Al2O3-CTAB(0.4)-500 with different mass in the range 3-15 mg to obtain kinetic parameters of the H2 release. In a typical experiment, the hydrolysis reaction was performed starting with 5 mg Rh/Al2O3-CTAB(0.4)-500 at various temperatures (298, 303, 308, and 313 K) to obtain the activation energy. 2.5 Recyclability of Rh/Al2O3 catalyst in dehydrogenation reaction Recyclability and durability of catalyst is an important factor to determine the practical application of catalyst. At the beginning of the consecutive runs, 10 mg optimal catalyst was placed in the reactor and the reaction was carried out as described above. After completing a run, the reactor was charged with 17.2 mg (0.5 mmol) of AB to begin the next one. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Structural characterization of catalysts A series of catalysts of Rh/Al2O3 were synthesized by directly ball milling aluminum nitrate and RhCl3·3H2O using hexadecyl trimethyl ammonium bromide (CTAB) as a structure modifier, and then calcined in air without any reduction treatment (Supporting Information for details). The schematic diagram is showed in Scheme 1. The prepared catalysts were named Rh/Al2O3-CTAB(X)-T (where X represents the amount of CTAB and T represents the roasting temperature). To understand the structure property of the Rh/Al2O3 catalysts, N2 adsorption and desorption characterization were carried out at 77 K. As shown in Fig. 1a-c, and g-i, all Rh/Al2O3 catalysts showed type IV isothermal adsorption and desorption curves, corresponding to the mesoporous materials. The pore size distributions of these catalysts are shown in Fig. 1. The pore sizes of all catalysts are in the range of 5-20 nm, which further illustrate the mesoporous structure of these prepared catalysts. Specific surface area and the average pore size of these catalysts are summarized and listed in Table 1 . The BET specific surface area of the synthesized catalyst Rh/Al2O3-CTAB(0)-400 was only 61.9 m2·g−1 under CTAB-free condition, while the BET specific surface area of other catalysts synthesized by adding CTAB as a structure modifier was substantially increased compared to that of Rh/Al2O3-CTAB(0)-400. For example, the BET specific surface area of Rh/Al2O3-CTAB(0.4)-400 has a BET specific surface area of 148.4 m2·g−1 and an average pore size of 6.3 nm. These results indicated that the BET specific surface area of catalysts can be effectively regulated by using CTAB as template agent. The effect of calcination temperature on the structure of the catalyst has also been investigated. As the calcination temperature increased to 500°C, the BET specific surface area of the catalyst Rh/Al2O3-CTAB(0.4)-500 increases significantly to 216.4 m2·g−1, but the average pore size decreases to 5.5 nm, presumably due to the formation of smaller mesopores due to the shrinkage of the pore structure at high calcination temperature. However, with the further increase of calcination temperature, the BET specific surface area of the catalyst Rh/Al2O3-CTAB(0.4)-600 decreases to 102.0 m2·g−1, and the average pore size also increases to 8.0 nm. It is due to the rapid decomposition of reactants at high temperature, resulting in the increase of the average pore size. Such high BET specific surface area also clearly indicates their rich porosity, confirming the great potential of these materials for applications in heterogeneous catalysis. The microstructure of the catalysts was surveyed by SEM. As shown from the SEM images of the prepared catalysts (Fig. 2a-f), it can be seen from Fig. 2a that Rh/Al2O3-CTAB(0)-400 has a an irregular morphology with a dense and rough surface structure. Compared with Rh/Al2O3-CTAB(0)-400, the other catalysts have a more rich pore structure, which indicates that the addition of CTAB in the preparation process can significantly change the surface morphology and pore structure of the catalysts. These results are basically consistent with the results of N2 adsorption and desorption isotherms. Further study the pore structure and rhodium nanoparticles of the catalyst Rh/Al2O3-CTAB(0.4)-500 by TEM was conducted, it can be seen that a small number of Rh nanoparticles are dispersed on the support (Fig. 2h) and catalyst possesses the rich pore structure. Noticeably, a few NPs can be identified by HRTEM where the lattice spacing of 0.222 nm of the nanoparticles can be indexed with certainty to the (111) crystal plane of Rh [50]. The EDX mappings (Fig. 2k-m) show that Rh was finely dispersed on the Al2O3 support without distinct Rh aggregations. These results indicate that Rh/Al2O3 catalyst with uniformly dispersed rhodium nanoparticles can be prepared by mechanochemical methods. The phase and crystal structure of the prepared catalysts were analyzed by powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD). As shown in Fig. 3a, only amorphous wide diffraction peaks are observed in all Rh/Al2O3 catalysts, indicating that the catalyst support is amorphous material. Further study the structural characteristics of the catalyst by XPS was conducted. As shown Figure S1, the Al 2p XPS signal has only one single peak at 74.3 eV, which is close to the previously reported Al 2p spectra of Al2O3 [51]. Based on the results of XRD and XPS, combined with the fact that aluminum nitrate is decomposed into Al2O3 at high temperature, we can infer that the support of the catalyst is amorphous Al2O3. The characteristic diffraction peak of Rh can not be observed from the results of XRD, it is due to the low content and small size of Rh species. In addition, XPS was also used to study the surface composition of catalysts and the chemical valence state of Rh species. Fig. 3b shows the survey spectrum of the catalyst and it can be observed that Rh is the only metallic element detected besides the alumina support. Fig. 4 shows the Rh 3d XPS spectra of the catalysts. Typically, the high resolution Rh 3d XPS scan of Rh/Al2O3-CTAB(0.4)-500 (Fig. 4a) shows two prominent peaks at 309.4 and 314.1 eV, which are attributed to the oxide species of rhodium [52,53]. Moreover, the lower energy peaks observed at 307.3 and 311.7 eV can be ascribed to the metallic rhodium [54,55], and this metallic rhodium comes from the reduction of trivalent rhodium in the process of self-assembly. Similar results have been found in other Rh/Al2O3 catalysts (Fig. 4b-f), that is, the most rhodium species exist in the form of oxidation, only a small part in the form of metal rhodium. 3.2 Evaluation of catalytic activity for hydrolysis of ammonia borane After clarifying the structure of the catalyst, we tested the activity of the catalysts for hydrolysis of AB. The catalytic activity was evaluated by monitoring the volume of generated hydrogen. As shown in Fig. 5a, Rh/Al2O3-CTAB(0)-400 is active, and AB was hydrolyzed within 16 min to produce a stoichiometric hydrogen, indicating that mechanochemical preparation of Rh/Al2O3 is an effective and feasible method. Improve the activity of the catalyst was achieved by adding a template of CTAB in the process of catalyst preparation. Notably, Rh/Al2O3-CTAB(0.4)-400 shows the highest catalytic activity, which is closely related to its abundant porosity. Based on these results, we controlled the dosage of CTAB to 0.4 g and adjusted the calcination temperature to 500 and 600°C. The catalytic performance of Rh/Al2O3 prepared at different temperatures is shown in Fig. 5b. When the calcination temperature is 500°C, the catalytic activity is further improved, and its TOF value can reach 186.0 min−1, which is calculated based on the ICP-MS results. This is due to the fact that catalysts prepared at this temperature form a richer pore structure with a higher specific surface area, which is conducive to the contact of the reactants and the active species. In addition, the pore size is also closely related to the activity of the catalyst, which can play a limiting role in the dehydrogenation process. The most suitable average pore size was found to be around 5.5 nm, which is good for the diffusion of reactants and products. When the temperature is further increased to 600°C, the specific surface area of the catalyst decreases sharply, and the average pore size increases to 8 nm. It is due to the rapid decomposition of reactants at high temperature, resulting in the increase of the average pore size, obviously not conducive to the reaction. Therefore, Rh/Al2O3-CTAB(0.4)-500 with the best catalytic activity was selected from all the prepared catalysts as the preferred catalyst for further study. The catalytic kinetics was studied by evaluating the reaction effect of different catalyst dosages. As shown in Fig. 5c, the rate of hydrogen production increases with the increase of the catalyst dose. Accordingly, the Rh concentration and hydrogen production rate can be plotted in logarithmic coordinates. A straight line with a slope of 1.23 is obtained from the Fig. 5d, indicating that the hydrolysis of AB catalyzed by Rh/Al2O3-CTAB(0.4)-500 is a quasi-first-order reaction with respect to Rh concentration. The effect of temperature on the catalytic performance the catalyst has also been investigated (Fig. 6). Take the catalytic dehydrogenation of Rh/Al2O3-CTAB(0.4)-500 at different temperatures as an example, it can be see that the rate of hydrogen production increases with increasing temperature (Fig. 6h), indicating that controllable generation of hydrogen can be achieved by changing the hydrolysis temperature. Furthermore, the activation energy of 44.8 kJ·mol−1 for the hydrolysis of AB catalyzed by Rh/Al2O3-CTAB(0.4)-500 can also be obtained from the slope of the Arrhenius plot in Fig. 6k. Using the same method, activation energies of other catalysts were also acquired (Fig. 6), and the results are summarized in Table 1. It is worth noting that among these catalysts, Rh/Al2O3-CTAB(0.4)-500 has the lowest activation energy, indicating that catalyst Rh/Al2O3-CTAB(0.4)-500 is less dependent on temperature, that is, catalyst Rh/Al2O3-CTAB (0.4)-500 can also maintain its good catalytic activity at low temperature [32]. In addition, Table 2 summarizes the TOF and activation energies of the reported Rh-based catalysts for the hydrolysis of AB. The catalysts prepared in this study show moderate catalytic activity compared to those Rh-based catalysts that have been reported in literature. Nonetheless, it is still worthy of admiration that the mechanochemical method reported in this work shows great potential for the preparation of Rh/Al2O3 catalysts due to its simplicity and green preparation processes. Here, we propose a plausible reaction mechanism and is shown in Scheme 2 . In brief, AB molecules are firstly adsorbed and then interact with metal particle surface to form activated complex Rh-H species which is then dissociates upon attack by H2O to release H2 [19,56]. As shown in Figure S2, the proportion of Rh(0) increased significantly, indicating that the high valence rhodium species was reduced to Rh(0) during this process, and a large number of metaborate by-products were generated [57]. So, the formation of the Rh-H is the prerequisite for the hydrolytic reaction. The high activity of the Rh/Al2O3-CTAB(0.4)-500 was related to the easy formation of Rh-H. Furthermore, the high specific surface area and appropriate pore structure of the Al2O3 also improve the utilization of Rh atoms, thus improving the activity of the catalyst. 3.3 Cyclic performance of catalyst Recyclability of Rh/Al2O3-CTAB(0.4)-500 was investigated by repeating the catalytic reaction five times (Fig. 7 ). It can be seen intuitively that the catalytic activity decayed gradually as the cycle number increased which is due to the growth of the Rh NPs and the accumulation of the by-product. Indeed, compared with the latter several runs, the catalytic activity of the second run decreased more sharply. It is due to the agglomeration of Rh NPs during the reaction. The adsorption of metaborate on the surface of the catalyst causes the coverage of the active sites, which is also the reason for the sharp decrease of the activity [63]. Nevertheless, the molar ratios of H2 to AB can still reach three even at the 5th catalytic cycle, indicating complete hydrolysis of AB. In addition, the catalyst was also separated from the suspension after the reaction and named Rh/Al2O3-CTAB(0.4)-500-Reduced, corresponding SEM image (Fig. 2g) shows that its morphology did not change significantly even after the reaction, indicating that the catalyst Rh/Al2O3-CTAB(0.4)-500 possesses certain reusability. 4 Conclusions In summary, we have prepared Rh/meso-Al2O3 catalysts by a one-plot solid-state mechanochemical synthesis. The pore structure of Rh/Al2O3 catalysts can be controlled by simply adjusting the amount of template agent and calcination temperature. The specific surface area of optimal catalyst Rh/Al2O3-CTAB(0.4)-500 can reach up 216.4 m2·g−1, and it exhibits good catalytic activity for AB hydrolysis with the TOF value up to 186.0 molH2·molRh −1·min−1 at 298 K. The high activity of the Rh/Al2O3-CTAB(0.4)-50 is closely related to its large BET specific surface area and appropriate average pore size. The reaction kinetic study catalyzed by the optimal catalyst Rh/Al2O3-CTAB(0.4)-500 shows that the hydrolysis of AB is a quasi-first-order reaction. Furthermore, Rh/Al2O3-CTAB(0.4)-500 can be reused and is able to fully catalyze the hydrolysis of AB after five cycles, which indicates it has relatively good reusability. As a result, this study offers a simple but efficient strategy to construct Rh/Al2O3 as an excellent heterogeneous catalyst for hydrolytic dehydrogenation of AB. coredata.dc:description: Aluminium oxide (Al2O3) is a promising catalyst support due to its excellent stability, high specific surface area, low price, and wide applicability. At present, most of the synthesis methods of Al2O3 are wet chemical process, and the solid-state synthesis of catalysts is underdeveloped under solvent-free conditions. In this study, we proposed a novel strategy for solvent-free synthesis of Rh/Al2O3 catalysts via mechanochemistry. The pore properties of the catalysts can be tuned by simply adjusting the amount of template CTAB and calcination temperatures. As a proof of concept, as-prepared catalysts are used to catalyze hydrolytic dehydrogenation of ammonia borane. The best catalyst Rh/Al2O3-CTAB(0.4)-500 achieves a total turnover frequency of 186.0 molH2·molRh −1·min−1 at 298 K and the activation energy is 44.8 kJ·mol−1. It also exhibits good cycling properties for catalyzing the hydrolysis of ammonia borane completely even after five runs. The catalysts were also characterized by various methods, including SEM, TEM, XPS, XRD, etc., to study the relationship between their structure and catalytic performance. The results show that the high activity of the catalyst is closely related to its large BET specific surface area and appropriate average pore size.
coredata.dc:title: Solid-state mechanochemical synthesis of Rh/Al2O3 catalysts for effective hydrolysis of ammonia borane
